newsitem.title: TAIWAN: FOCUS - Taiwan joblessness easing as recovery warms.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Taiwan joblessness easing as recovery warms.

text.p: Taiwan on Friday announced a surprisingly low jobless rate in April, and economists said the downward trend should persist as the domestic recovery strengthens, especially in industrial output.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said April unemployment was 2.59 percent, lower than government and private economists had expected.
The figure was well below an average 2.896 forecast compiled from a May 21 Reuters Poll of Taiwan economists.

"With the gradually strengthening recovery, our jobless rate likely will fall to meet the government's target of 2.6 percent for 1997," agency director Chen Chang-hsiung told reporters after announcing the April figure.
The cabinet's Council for Economic Planning and Development has set a joblessness target of 2.6 percent for 1997. In the January-April period, unemployment averaged 2.76 percent.
Experts said Taiwan's recovery was creating new jobs.
"Domestic industrial output had shown 10 straight months of growth, effectively helping stabilise or reduce the high jobless rate," said National Securities economist Lin Kuo-yang.
"First half exports are seen maintaining stable five percent growth and likely will perform better in the second half," Lin said. "All these should back up a declining jobless rate."
Taiwan said on Wednesday its April industrial output rose 6.12 percent year-on-year.

Directorate economists said April's relatively low jobless figure was a surprise -- confounding expectations that an islandwide outbreak of hog foot-and-mouth disease in March and a related ban on Taiwan's huge pork exports would cost jobs.
"The impact of the hog epidemic was lower than expected, partly because many pork processors did not lay off workers but only reduced their working hours," Chen said.
Chen said precise figures for epidemic-related job losses, when available in mid-June, would not be especially high.

Besides banning all pork exports temporarily, the government responded to the outbreak by ordering the slaughter of all hogs, even healthy ones, at all affected farms -- or about four million of Taiwan's 14 million pigs.

Chen confirmed that a steadily accelerating recovery was key to a month-on-month decline from the 2.79 percent jobless rate in March, saying a rebound in manufacturing and the long-struggling construction sector was creating jobs.

Economists said numerous construction projects had been launched since late March in anticipation of recovering demand, though new political and social factors had the potential to keep potential home-buyers on the sidelines.

"People are taking a wait-and-see attitude on buying houses due to political worries over social disorder and the ongoing constitutional reforms, though this should not have much impact in terms of reducing employment," said Grand Cathay Securities vice-president Terry Chen.

The island's jobless rate hovered around 1.5 percent from 1991-1994, rose to 1.79 percent in 1995 and pushed above three percent for three months from August 1996 -- a dramatic rise for Taiwan -- before turning back downward.
Joblessness was 2.6 percent for all of 1996, a 10-year high.
